text: Morning all, just to outline the details. Have a system that looks to suggest Ranks to either Back or Lay. Rank is the order of favouritism as determined by BSP. My monetary results are based up correct Rank being selected and a £25 Back bet or £25 Lay bet achieved at BSP. £25 was chosen when I set up my database as a figure that should be able to be matched around the off time. In reality this may not always be the case but this way I have a consistent approach. I am not at the implementation stage yet. Other caveats, I do not consider the odds when Laying. In reality I would not be placing £25 on 1000 BSP even though this might show up as a win in the results however having some visibility on the impact when a high odds Lay goes on to win I`m hoping will give some pointers on frequency and risk reward at the implementation stage. I have shown visibility on Ranks 11 & 12 although they do not feature in the daily total so I can compare the rate of progress to other systems on test. This is what I believe to be the results for Mon assuming my sums/data is correct. To clarify, getting matched on the correct Rank is more important than any odds changes to the BSP value when getting matched. As a measure of success or failure I count the No of suggestions then the No that have a value >£0.00. New system so thus far Count = 79, CountIF >£0 = 60. I`m hoping that posting here will turn into a bit of a peer review.

text: Id suggest downloading the daily BSP files, splitting your model data into 80% and 20% roughly. Build your script/ decision maker off of the 80% of the historical data, do not let it see the  other 20%. Once you have fully come up with the script / decision maker rules, return to the 20% and see if it makes profit.

text: This is the typical learning approach from machine learning. Take your all the historical data you have and randomly shuffle it. Once shuffled take 20% of you data and put it aside, forget about it for now, almost like it doesn't exist.  With the remaining 80% you will use this data to come up with your model / script / decision maker. Apply the process of learning to this data solely making sure it never sees any of the 20% hidden away. A typical learning approach could be linear regression (gradient descent) but it can be as simple as using excel to filter records although this is sub optimal. Once you think you have constructed your model / script / decision maker, return to that 20% of data and apply the rules / model to it and evaluate performance.

elements.text: This is the typical learning approach from machine learning. Take your all the historical data you have and randomly shuffle it. Once shuffled take 20% of you data and put it aside, forget about it for now, almost like it doesn't exist.  With the remaining 80% you will use this data to come up with your model / script / decision maker. Apply the process of learning to this data solely making sure it never sees any of the 20% hidden away. A typical learning approach could be linear regression (gradient descent) but it can be as simple as using excel to filter records although this is sub optimal. Once you think you have constructed your model / script / decision maker, return to that 20% of data and apply the rules / model to it and evaluate performance.

text: The performance in the 80% is somewhat irrelevant and should be mainly disregarded, its the 20% you care about

text: I am looking at historical data to try to determine what the likely outcome might be going forward based upon what happened in the past. No rocket science behind it unfortunately.

elements.text: I am looking at historical data to try to determine what the likely outcome might be going forward based upon what happened in the past. No rocket science behind it unfortunately.

text:
I think like you suggested at the very start you need to change your overall thinking / mentality when coming up with strategy ideas. 

Very first thing is have an idea of where there might be value and possibly why. Imagine a specific point in time and you see odds at 2.1, is backing at that price cheap? Is 2.15 cheap? Is 2.2 cheap? How can you determine if any particular bet is cheap? For me, that’s what a strategy is - a method of determining a fair price so that I can either back or lay with a margin on top of the fair price. 

If you base things on ordering, why would the 3rd favourite necessarily be cheap or expensive based on history? For me the 3rd favourite has just as much probability of being either, so any trend you find in historical data will turn out to be you fitting to the data. 

So I recommend going back to the basics and write down 10 ideas of how you can measure whether a price is cheap or expensive to back or lay. Then test those ideas to see if they are actually a good measure.

elements.text: I think like you suggested at the very start you need to change your overall thinking / mentality when coming up with strategy ideas.

Very first thing is have an idea of where there might be value and possibly why. Imagine a specific point in time and you see odds at 2.1, is backing at that price cheap? Is 2.15 cheap? Is 2.2 cheap? How can you determine if any particular bet is cheap? For me, that’s what a strategy is - a method of determining a fair price so that I can either back or lay with a margin on top of the fair price. 

If you base things on ordering, why would the 3rd favourite necessarily be cheap or expensive based on history? For me the 3rd favourite has just as much probability of being either, so any trend you find in historical data will turn out to be you fitting to the data. 

So I recommend going back to the basics and write down 10 ideas of how you can measure whether a price is cheap or expensive to back or lay. Then test those ideas to see if they are actually a good measure.

root.text: I am looking at historical data to try to determine what the likely outcome might be going forward based upon what happened in the past. No rocket science behind it unfortunately.

elements.text: I am looking at historical data to try to determine what the likely outcome might be going forward based upon what happened in the past. No rocket science behind it unfortunately.

text:
<@U01PQ9SR9MJ> the point is that your conclusion of "what is the likely outcome going forward" is unlikely to be useful unless you evaluate this conclusion on data you have not incorporated when doing your data mining. To put it simply, you can't say that your observation of some pattern is a useful observation unless you find that this observation is profitable on data you have kept seperate from where you identified this pattern in the first place. indeed you are attempting to do something like this with your "forward testing", but you can very easily learn the results of your forward testing by just holding out some of your historical data. (This is of course not to disqualify the usefulness of actually taking your strategy to the market with small stakes).

also to add - if you are relying on real trading to do this "validation" for you, your whole process is going to be slow. By holding out some historical data you can instantly check if the patterns you've identified have some profitability (and  therefore meaning you have not just overfit your historical data set).

text: Just as an example, some people might have fast data feeds so they can see live scores or horse positions faster than other people. From that they can determine what a fair price is more accurately than the general market can. Or alternatively a lot of people will base a measure of fair price on what is happening in the market and what has been matched recently or whatever. Others will take fundamental information and calculate a fair price using that.

If I personally cannot determine what is value anyway then I have to disregard it but I can imagine within the mix there will be some value. Today like any other day there will be a mixture of Ranks that win and Ranks that lose. I`m looking to make a judgement or whatever you like to call it that it`s right more times than it`s wrong. There are tiers of detail you can go into like runner, rank, course etc. This is a stab at elevating to a higher tier where the meetings are all encompassed to a single decision to Back or Lay by Rank. Value included.

text:
I think technical analysis is an interesting one. It’s not something I’m immediately attracted to, but I think it can work in certain circumstances like Jon has demonstrated. So I think it’s more a case of considering whether technical analysis makes sense or not.  

I remember when I first dabbled in sports pricing, I thought I’d use technical analysis methods on tennis because I saw odds going up and down a lot. Obviously I soon realised that was a silly idea, since in tennis the future price isn’t governed by historical price movements - future price movements are purely (or mostly) a function of the score! However that’s not necessarily the case with pre-race horse racing for example.

text:
<@U01PQ9SR9MJ> It can be quite difficult to understand what "value" is and there is no binary answer to the question. The basic idea of making a profit is to place bets at prices greater than the true probability of an event happening. That could be horse winning a race or a football team losing, etc. The fact is that we never _truly_ know if the bet we are placing is good value or not and all we can do is make our best approximation. If our approximation is correct often enough, we make a profit. Sometimes we get it right, sometimes we get it wrong, but as long as we're right more often than the market, we make a profit. Unlike tossing coins, rolling dice or spinning roulette wheels, sports betting does NOT have probabilities that can be calculated exactly, so at best, we're using educated guesses. Whether intentional or not, strategies like "lay the favourite", "back the outsider", etc will only show a profit IF they are finding value.

Regarding backtesting, as others have mentioned, you are trying to predict _future_ patterns, so building a strategy using _all_ of your data only tells you what happened in the past. The problem is overfitting, where, through multiple filter adjustments and fine tuning, you end up picking all the sweet spots from events that have already happened. It's no different to shopping...if the item you want to buy is £10 today but was £8 yesterday, you will have to pay £10 for it because yesterday's price has now gone. Your strategy may tell you to buy at £8, but that's no longer available, so it's not a true value. You _can_ build a strategy using _all_ of your data but then you would have to place real bets and wait a long time to see if it's actually profitable. OR you can split the data into a "training" set and a "validation" set, the validation set representing the "future" data. It's critical to ensure that while developing the strategy that you _never_ use the validation data as it's for...you guessed it...validation only.

After many years at this game (I was botting <http://Flutter.com|Flutter.com> via browser emulation before Betfair bought them out in ~2002) I had also become very stuck in my thought process. I have a handful of bots that have earnt small amounts for many years but never enough to actually live off. Joining this Slack group was the best thing I've done in the last 20 years. The quality of knowledge collected here is second to none and the members are more than happy to answer stupid questions (and I've asked a lot of them!). I've recently had an epiphany after reading <https://www.amazon.co.uk/Logic-Sports-Betting-Ed-Miller/dp/1096805723|The Logic Of Sports Betting> and listening to the <https://player.fm/series/business-of-betting-podcast|Business Of Betting> podcasts, both of which were recommended on this group. Don't be put off by negative comments, they're actually a very truthful lot on here and, believe it or not ARE trying to help.

attachments.title: Business of Betting Podcast
attachments.text: A betting podcast about the business side of the betting, wagering and investing world.

text: :sunglasses:

One question I have is what do you do when you've created a strategy using the test data and then when you come to use the validation data the strategy doesn't perform as well as you hoped?

Because you could go back and tweak some parameters and then rerun the strategy on the validation data, but by doing that your validation data has now effectively become your test data.  So how do you refine/improve a strategy after you've used the validation data?

elements.text:

Because you could go back and tweak some parameters and then rerun the strategy on the validation data, but by doing that your validation data has now effectively become your test data.  So how do you refine/improve a strategy after you've used the validation data?

text: Split your data in two: an in sample set and an out of sample. The latter is what you use a final test of “does this strategy generalise to unseen data”. Then you split the in sample further into train/test data sets. You do your tweaking on those. Once you’ve done finished all your tweaking, then you finally run that once on the OOS set.

elements.text: Split your data in two: an in sample set and an out of sample. The latter is what you use a final test of “does this strategy generalise to unseen data”. Then you split the in sample further into train/test data sets. You do your tweaking on those. Once you’ve done finished all your tweaking, then you finally run that once on the OOS set.

text: <@U01DJ4DBF9R> is correct. But remember once you have checked on OOS, don’t then go back, tweak your models and then reuse that OOS. That OOS gets effectively “burned” even though your model never saw it in training or validation

elements.text: is correct. But remember once you have checked on OOS, don’t then go back, tweak your models and then reuse that OOS. That OOS gets effectively “burned” even though your model never saw it in training or validation

text: I must say this Slack group is good. Can I just confirm if i've got this epiphany right. So i've been trying to come up with a bot based on patterns I preceive in price/volume/traded prices etc... When in fact I should really just try and estimate "value" and trade when I see it...?

elements.text: I must say this Slack group is good. Can I just confirm if i've got this epiphany right. So i've been trying to come up with a bot based on patterns I preceive in price/volume/traded prices etc... When in fact I should really just try and estimate "value" and trade when I see it...?

text:
Yes, by cheap I mean good value. 

You can either measure 2.2 as a good value back if BSP is lower, like you say. Or if on average all the bets you match at 2.2 win more often than 1/2.2 = 45.45% of the time. Of course the latter requires lots of data to verify. 

Ultimately it’s sort of a tautology. If your bets are value then you can show that they make money, similarly if you are making money your bets must be value.

elements.text: Yes, by cheap I mean good value.

You can either measure 2.2 as a good value back if BSP is lower, like you say. Or if on average all the bets you match at 2.2 win more often than 1/2.2 = 45.45% of the time. Of course the latter requires lots of data to verify. 

Ultimately it’s sort of a tautology. If your bets are value then you can show that they make money, similarly if you are making money your bets must be value.

text:
I mean you could argue that these “patterns” are what’s telling what a fair / value price is. But personally I don’t use technical analysis methods, or at least none that use much of a price history. I find that technical patterns require far too many arbitrary parameters which need to be determined from the past history which ultimately leads to overfitting. Like if you’re using a moving average for something, what size window at what frequency? Why does any particular window make more sense than anything else?

So yeah, I’d try and think of more mathematical or explainable reasons why something might happen and use that as a starting point for searching for value.

elements.text: I mean you could argue that these “patterns” are what’s telling what a fair / value price is. I find that technical patterns require far too many arbitrary parameters which need to be determined from the past history which ultimately leads to overfitting. Like if you’re using a moving average for something, what size window at what frequency? Why does any particular window make more sense than anything else?
So yeah, I’d try and think of more mathematical or explainable reasons why something might happen and use that as a starting point for searching for value.

text: Yeah, there will certainly be parties that price things using fundamentals, and some of these people take home some of the biggest sums. However don’t under estimate the amount of data required to go into modelling who wins a horse race for example. I’d say fundamental modelling is one of the more advanced methods and shouldn’t be tackled unless you’re already confident you have a chance of success.

text:
Well I’d suggest you just have a think about times when there might be value in the market, or what things might give you a clue about value. 

Eg. When overrounds are near 100% or when there’s a large spread. Or just when a race goes in-play, or when a price reaches a high point for the very first time, or when prices reach price crossover points, or when a horse is withdrawn, or look at NSP and FSP predictions, or good old weight of money, etc...

text: Well if it typically goes higher, perhaps that means it’s a good value lay. You won’t know until you backtest these things. But that’s just an example. You need to think of your own ideas as to where there might be value and test it.

text:
Try not to look at charts in my opinion. That’s too large a window. What happened at the start of that chart probably has no bearing on what’s happening now. 

Try and think of very short instances or situations. What is a situation that happens quite frequently each day, then hunt for value in that specific situation. 

The betting markets are very efficient when you look at them as a whole. It’s only when you’re more specific that you might find value systematically.

The betting markets are very efficient when you look at them as a whole. It’s only when you’re more specific that you might find value systematically.

text:
To add to the above, humans are creatures of habit. Humans create bots. Humans perceive patterns in numbers that don't have any actual significance...like the time being 11:11 or 12:34. Humans rarely place their bets 17.35738 seconds before a race starts.
Forget about trying to predict which runner or player will win the race and think more about things like "why did the favourite drift 30 seconds before the scheduled start time?" or "how did that £1000 bet affect the market?".

text: Anyone good enough can make money on any sport. That does not mean it is easy, just that there is room for a large number of successful players, and always enough for one more

elements.text: Anyone good enough can make money on any sport. That does not mean it is easy, just that there is room for a large number of successful players, and always enough for one more

text: There is also no such thing as "too efficient". On UK racing there are a few syndicates making huge money on pre-off UK racing. And my view is that these models, while incredibly detailed and profitable, will all lead to different prices for different runners

elements.text: There is also no such thing as "too efficient". On UK racing there are a few syndicates making huge money on pre-off UK racing. And my view is that these models, while incredibly detailed and profitable, will all lead to different prices for different runners

text: So player 1 might get a huge win on a race, while player 2 might make a huge loss. Sometimes profits will coincide, sometimes not. Some runners will be bet on by one model but not others

elements.text: So player 1 might get a huge win on a race, while player 2 might make a huge loss. Sometimes profits will coincide, sometimes not. Some runners will be bet on by one model but not others

text: While not commenting on which is easier (some on this forum do both, or have done both, so may have a view), the major differences are much bigger liquidity on UK racing and a smaller number of tracks, runners, and jockeys, etc

elements.text: While not commenting on which is easier (some on this forum do both, or have done both, so may have a view), the major differences are much bigger liquidity on UK racing and a smaller number of tracks, runners, and jockeys, etc

text: Another one for newbies. Until you have a very good and reliable automated system, probably best to work in your own time zone. When you run overnight with no manual monitoring, it's very easy for something to go wrong and drain your account :wink:

elements.text: Another one for newbies. Until you have a very good and reliable automated system, probably best to work in your own time zone. When you run overnight with no manual monitoring, it's very easy for something to go wrong and drain your account

text: Lastly, the biggest syndicates with the most money and influence on prices will bet late pre-off - mostly in the last 5 minutes. If I were to do racing pre-off I would look to betting prior to that money entering the market. That's just my view

elements.text: Lastly, the biggest syndicates with the most money and influence on prices will bet late pre-off - mostly in the last 5 minutes. If I were to do racing pre-off I would look to betting prior to that money entering the market. That's just my view

text: Helps if you realize that not a lot of people are thinking in this value-seeking way. People trade for different reasons and at different times, and this creates the noise in the market.

elements.text: Helps if you realize that not a lot of people are thinking in this value-seeking way. People trade for different reasons and at different times, and this creates the noise in the market.

text: You shouldn't assume any market is too efficient, that kind of thinking will hold you back. But as <@USYQKE5HN> has done a stellar job of explaining, you should think about scenarios where markets may be inefficient and where you can find value. For example, we can absolutely say that the horse racing markets are more efficient at the off than they are 1 day before
